projectDesc.p: The corpus presents a sample of medieval and early modern Gaelic manuscript materials from Scotland.

samplingDecl.p: Manuscripts materials are selected with a view to ensuring representation of all periods, dialects, registers, orthographies, genres, and topics for which materials for which materials are extant.

correction.p: Where a manuscript form appears to be a misspelling with no linguistic significance, the spelling is corrected using the <add> element if one or more characters have been omitted or the <sic> and <corr> elements for variant characters or more complex emendations. The <add> element is also used for later scribal additions; the type of addition is determined by the @resp attribute.Where characters are difficult to read due to damage to the script or due to physical damage, one or more provisional readings are provided using the <unclear> element, with a @cert level.

normalization.p: As this project is about supplying the forms used by Gaelic scribes, as well as authors, in Scotland, manuscript forms will usually not be normalized and never normalized silently. As stated above, normalization will only be carried out in cases of clear and potentially misleading scribal error. Where available, lemma data will be added to the <w> element using the @lemma attribute. A reference to the most appropriate dictionary will be added using @lemmaRef. Where a word contains multiple potential lemmata (e.g. a compound verb), it will be encoded as a single word containing several words (i.e. with outer and inner <w> elements). For more details, see below. Words that contain multipel syntactic units but where these units might be expected to appear within the dictionary entry on that word (e.g. conjugated prepositions) will remain within a single <w> element.

Both scribal and analytic word division will be encoded; which is to be displayed will be determined by the stylesheet. The the <space/> element will be used to represent scribal or orthographic word division. The word (<w>) element will be used to indicate editorial word division. Verse (<l> and <lg>) division will be normalised where the metre can be securely interpreted from the manuscript text of a poem.

punctuation.p: Scribal punctuation is followed at all times. Rendering may vary in the published forms of transcriptions. For example, a scribe may delete text by placing dots beneath it; this text would be placed within the <del> element and rendered with a strikethrough. Also, a later addition by a scribe using an insertion mark will be represented with the <add> element but the insertion mark itself will not be represented.

segmentation.p: Segmentation differs depending on whether the text is prose or verse

All texts, at the lowest level, are segemented by word (<w>). Some compound words (e.g. conjunct verbs with preverbal particles or some compound nouns) are further segmented by <w> elements within the outer <w> element. The inner <w> element encloses a morpheme that could constitute a lemma in its own right and which cannot be subdivided into further lemmata. This is done in cases where both the compound word as a whole could also constitute a lemma. For example, do-beir is both a lemma in eDIL and contains the do- preverbal particle, which is a lemma in eDIL in its own right. In such cases, in the outer <w> element, the @lemma, @lemmaRef, and @ana attributes will include data for all the lemmata contained in the inner <w> element elements seperated by whitepace. Very occasionally, three levels of <w> elements might be needed to capture all the potential lemmata in a word.

Similarly, proper names are enclosed in the <name> element with the @type attribute, then the names' components are enclosed in one or more inner <w> elements. This means that names can be excluded from search but, if they are included, their components can be retrieved in the same way as other nouns.

Prose texts are not segmented by sentence. This will be an arbitrary decision in many cases (punctuation and capitals being absent) and it is unnecessary, since context in the DASG Corpus is determined by word count rather than by sentence segmentation. If a prose text is clearly organised into units (e.g. some medical texts consist of commentary around propositions), then the <ab> element will be used to delineate these..
Verse texts are segmented by line (<l>) and stanza (<lg>).

Slips created by Ronald Black during the HDSG project are currently being digitised by DASG and it is an aim of this project to integrate this material into the metadata on the corpus. Thus, segments that have also been transcribed on a slip will be contained in the <seg> element and a link provided to the corresponding digitised slip.

A transcription file (a <text> in the <teiCorpus>) corresponds to a physical manuscript. If multiple texts are being transcribed from the same manuscript, then the <div1> element will be used to subdivide them within the file. If one text contains another text (e.g. a prose text with a verse citation), then <div2> and so on will be used to segment this text.

The <lb/> element, with attribute @n, will be used to indicate a new line in the manuscript. This is a distinct and seperate segementation system from <l>, which segments metrical lines. To publish a diplomatic edition of a verse text, use <lb/>; to publish a metrically analysed version of the text, use <lg> and <l>.

Sections of text in other languages (e.g. Latin) appear in some transcriptions. Other languages will be indicated at the <w> level using the @lang attribute. If a <w> element has no @lang attribute, it can be assumed to be Gaelic of some sort. Each Gaelic text's linguistic profile will be set out in the relevant <msItem> and under <langUsage> in the <teiHeader>. As much commentary as possible will be provided on the different linguistic strata in each text but it is expected that more will be discovered in the course of analysis.

taxonomy.gloss: - the interpretation of this word is doubtful.
- some characters in this word are difficult to decipher.
- this word is based on the doubtful expansion of an abbreviation.
- loss of vellum means some characters have had to be supplied.

glyph.note: The scribal abbreviation is unknown. This will probably be because the manuscript is now illegible and an edition is being used. The editor will have indicated that an abbreviation has been expanded but given no details.
A horizontal line with a downwards hook on the right-hand side, most frequently standing for "-m", or, occasionally "m" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
Resembles a "7" and may stand for "ocus" and variants or "et" and variants.
A superscript or mid-level horizontal stroke that may stand for any character(s).
May appear as a superscript punctum, spiritus asper or breve; adds an "-h" to consonants (i.e. lenites).
A horizontal superscript line, standing for "n". Often indistinguishable from a generic suspension stroke.
An anti-clockwise loop on top of a consonant, frequently representing "ir" but with some variability in the vowel.
Resembles a semi-colon (;) and generally stands for "us" but with some variability in the vowel.
An "a" with a descender on the right-hand side (very like "q"), with a cross-stroke on the descender, standing for "ar".
An punctum both before and after a letter or set of letters that may stand for any character(s).
An "s" with a horizontal superscript suspension stroke. Originally for Latin "sed" but used to represent "(e/a/ea)ch(t/d)" in Gaelic contexts.
An "a" with a descender on the right-hand side (very like "q"), with a cross-stroke on the descender, and superscript "i" standing for "air".
A superscript "c", usually standing for "c" preceded by a vowel and/or followed by "h".
An "a" with a descender on the right-hand side (very like "q"), with two cross-strokes on the descender, standing for "arr".
Two horizontal superscript or mid-level lines, standing for "nn".
A superscript "o", usually standing for "or" or "ro".
A superscript u/v, or wavy superscript stroke, usually standing for "u(i)r" or "ru".
A superscript "a", usually standing for "ra" or "ra".
A symbol resembling the Arabic number 2 and standing for Latin "est" or Gaelic orthographic equivalents. May be in-line with the text or superscript.
A "u" with a descender on the right-hand side with cross-stroke and a superscript "i"; stands for "uir".
A superscript "e", usually standing for standing for "er" or "re".
A vertical tilde, most often standing for "e(a)r" but may also represent "(e)ir".
Two vertical tildes, most often standing for "e(a)rr" but may also represent "(e)irr".
Two superscript or mid-level horizontal strokes, generally indicating that the expansion contains a double consonant.
A superscript "d", standing for a "d" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
A superscript "i", usually standing for "ri" or "ir".
An Arabic numeral "2", in-line or superscript, usually standing for "dá" or "da" in Gaelic contexts and "duo" in Latin contexts.
There is no visual indicator of an abbreviation but it is apparent for some reason that a word has been abbreviated, e.g. a single letter standing for a frequently-used name.
A reversed "c", standing for "co(n)", or a word beginning with "con".
A superscript "t", sanding for a "t" with preceding or succeeding letter(s). Sometimes modified with "i" and/or lenition.
Latin letter "q", standing for "cu".
The Arabic numeral 7, standing for "se(a)ch(t/d)" or similar.
Ligatured tironian et and rl with cross stroke, standing for either "et reliqua" or "ocus araile" and orthographic variants.
A descending character, looped on the right-hand side, standing for "m". This is usually attached to the previous letter and generally has three (or more) loops.
Letter "p" with a back-pointing tail on the descender standing for "pro".
An Arabic numeral "9", usually standing for "n" with succeding vowel(s), e.g. "na", "noi", "naoi".
A "p" with a cross stroke on the descender, usually standing for "per", "par" or "por".
The Arabic numeral 9, flipped vertically, standing for "an".
Superscript "io", usually standing for "ior".
Double e, which may appear with supersript puncta, standing for "eile". May also be accompanied by enclosing puncta.
A superscript b, standing for a "b" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
Double "l" with bisecting mid-level cross stroke, generally, but not always, standing for a multi-syllabic abbreviation.
A superscript "s", often a majuscule "s" without the lower leftward loop, standing for an "s" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
An "ae" digraph, with a crossed descender on the "a" (i.e. "ar"), standing for "aer" and possibly also "are".
A long insular "s" with a cross-stroke, standing for "s", with succeeding letter(s).
An "l" with a suspension stroke, standing for Latin "vel" or Gaelic "no" and orthographic variants.
An "i" with a cross-stroke, often set below the inner writing tracks, standing for "ir".
Superscript double "l" with bisecting mid-level cross stroke, generally, but not always, standing for a multi-syllabic abbreviation.
A curly, left-facing descender (not unlike a us symbol) with a cross-stroke, standing for "-uir", or perhaps "-air".
A Roman "k", mostly standing for "cath", although can also stand for "kalends". May be accompanied by enclosing puncta.
A left-facing superscript semi-circle, standing for "-s", perhaps with a preceding letter(s).
An "x", standing either for the numeral 10; for the spelling "dec", "deith", or similar; or for the spelling "ex" or "ecs".
A stroke from the lower left of a character to the upper right, crossing the character itself, standing for a string of subsequent letters.
The same character repeated, standing for that character capitalised.
Two puncta, one above the other, standing for any character(s).
An Arabic numeral "2" with a diagonal stroke across, standing for for "dai".
Letters "cc", standing for an abbreviation for a word starting with "cc".
A superscript "l", standing for an "l" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
Superscript "il", standing for a "il" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
A superscript "r", standing for a "r" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).

Letter "q" with an additional stroke originating at the right-hand side of the triangular body of the "q". The stroke extends a little to the right before curving downwards to the left and across the descender. This stands for "cu" in Gaelic contexts and "quod" in Latin contexts.
A Roman "z" with a diagonal cross-stroke, standing stands an "m" with preceding vowel in Latin genitive plurals.
A Roman capital "R" standing for "cath". Appears to be an alternative but distinct form of Roman "K" abbreviation for cath.
A single punctum placed after a letter, usually standing for the rest of a well-known or frequently-used word or name.

Ligature form of the letter "a" with superscript suspension stroke which is connected to the body of the letter at the top on the right-hand side, standing for the "allmara" or "allmari" portion of the word "allmarach".

A symbol resembling the Arabic numeral "3" found in one text in this corpus where it is accompanied by a following "i" and where it represents the "guins" portion of "guinsi" a variant orthographic form of "a dh'ionnsaigh".
Double "o", which may be accompanied by two superscript puncta or acute strokes, standing for "eile" or variants.
Letter u with a descender on the right-hand side and two cross strokes standing for "urr".

glyph.glyphName: double Tironian Nota with suspenion strokes
glyph.note: Two Tironian Notas, shortened at both ends, with two short superscript suspension strokes standing for "eile" or variants.
Double "u" which may accompanied by a single punctum or enclosing puncta, standing for "uile".
An "h", which may accompanied by enclosing puncta, standing for "úa" or an inflected form thereof.
The character "ŋ", standing for "na".
An "r" with a cross-stroke on the descender, standing for "rr".
An "i", which may extend below the line, with two cross-strokes, standing for for "irr".
A descending character, looped on the right-hand side, standing for "n". This is usually attached to the previous letter and generally has two loops.
Double "i" with a thin acute plume on each, standing for "eile" or orthographic equivalents.
A "y" placed within enclosing puncta (.y.).
An "a" with a descender on the right-hand side (very like "q"), with two cross-strokes on the descender, and superscript "i", standing for "airr".

glyph.glyphName: Tironian Nota with suspension stroke as a single abbreviation
glyph.note: A Tironian Nota with a suspension stroke which, combined, stand for "enn" or "end".
A superscript "g", standing for a "g" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
The Arabic numeral 6, standing for "sé", "se", "sia", "sex" or variants thereof.
A superscript "e" over an "i", standing for "eirigh".
A digraph of "q" and the us symbol (which looks somewhat like a semi-colon, ;), but standing for Latin "que".
A superscript "m", standing for an "m" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
The Roman numeral "ii", standing for "da".

glyph.glyphName: Tironian Nota with double suspension stroke
glyph.note: A Tironian Nota with double suspension stroke which, combined, stand for "enn" or "end".
A superscript "n", standing for an "n" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
A hieroglyphic "+", standing for "cros" and similar.
Superscript "ic", usually over "m" and standing for "hic" in "mhic".
An "l", suspension stroke, and inverted "s", standing for "leiges".
Double "c" with accute or grave plumes, two puncta or two carons, standing for c(h)éile.
The letter "u/v" written twice in superscript, standing for "urr".
Letter "o" with superscript "e", which may have a punctum above the "o", standing for a form of Éire, usually inflected.
Letter "a" with a descender on the right-hand side (very like "q") with a cross-stroke on the descender and a ligatured "e", standing for "are".
Letter "a" with a descender on the right-hand side (very like "q") with a cross-stroke on the descender, superscript "i", and a ligatured "e", standing for" aire".
The letter "o" with an diagonal arch, beginning at the top of the letter on the left-hand side and extending upwards and to the right, standing for "agus".
An Arabic numeral "10", standing for "de(i)ch", "de(i)th", or similar.
Letter "i" with enclosing puncta, when used to supply characters of another word, standing for "edon" or similar.
A "q" with an ascender as well as a descender, resembling a backwards "þ", standing for "qui" in Latin contexts.
Double superscript "l", standing for a "ll" with preceding or succeeding letter(s).
An Arabic numeral "4", standing for "cethair", "cethra", or similar.
A "u" with a descender on the right-hand side and cross-stroke, standing for "ur".
An Arabic numeral "8", standing for "ocht" or similar.
A Roman numeral "ix", standing for "nae(i)", "nao(i)", "na(i)", and similar.
"ia" in superscript, usually in a Latin word, standing for the ending "-ia" plus one or more preceding characters.
"ia" in superscript, usually in a Latin word, standing for the ending "-ia" plus one or more preceding characters.
Two letters are placed together as a ligature; this is a generic category for ligatures for which a separate glyph has not been created.
An "h" with an "e" atop its ascender.
Various combinations of "a" and "c".
"r" run into "e", the former perhaps resembling "s".
"a" without a backstroke, followed by "o".
"rr", with the first "r" reduced to a single descender and its hook merged with the top of the descender of the second "r".
"et", with the middle stroke of "e" also the cross-stroke of "t" and the "e" enclosing the "t".
"a" without a backstroke, followed by "m".
"a" without a backstroke, followed by "e".
"a" without a backstroke, followed by "g".
"a" without a backstroke, followed by "d".
"a" without a backstroke, followed by "i".
"a" without a backstroke, followed by "t".
"n", with "a" dangling beneath the line, attached to the second minim of "n".
An "e" with an "a" dangling below, standing for "ea".
A "d" with a long back-stroke, standing for "di".
A "e" followed by an "r", whose serif replaces the middle cross-stroke of the "e"..
A tironian "et" whose backstroke is also the descender of the following "p".
"a" without a backstroke, followed by "s".
A tironian "et" whose backstroke is also the descender of the following "r".
Double "p": the loop of the first "p" is merged with the backstroke of the second "p".
Double "s" (minuscule): the first "s" is a simple descender, with the short loop merged with the serif on the second "s".
A tironian "et" whose backstroke is also the descender of the following "f".
A "d" whose back-stroke forms part of a following "o".
An "a" whose back-stoke forms one of the minims of a following "n".
An "a" whose back-stoke forms one of the minims of a following "u".
A "u" whose second minim is part of the loop of a following "d".
A ligatured "a", although taller than usuual, whose back-stoke forms one of the minims of a following "n", standing for "aen".
A reversed "s", sharing a backstroke with a following "p".
An "l" with a "z" attached in subscript, standing for "la".
An "c" with a downward flick at the lower end of the loop, standing for "ca".
An "a" whose back-stoke forms one of the minims of a following "b".
An "u" whose second stoke forms part of the loop of the following "a".
An "o" that also forms the back of the following "a".
An "a" whose back-stoke is formed by the following "b".
A tall loop, like the "e" component of "&", apparently standing for "ir" ("senoirig").
The end-points of the first "c" are joined to the back of the next "c".
The left side of the "r" is combined with the right side of the right hand descender of the "u" so it almost looks like "ri", but the two letters are connected by a stroke at line level.
The "a" is below the line and formed from a descender running off from the final minim of the "m".
A "c" ligatured with the following "r".
The standard abbreviation for "air", ligatured with a small "e" (like "ar symbol with ligatured e" but with a superscript "i").
A "p" whose loop forms the back of the curve on the following "e".
An "i" with an open "a" below, with one end of the "a" attached to the "i" minim.
A "b" whose loop forms part of the following "o".
A tironian et which also forms the back of the loop of a following "e".
An "h" with an open "a" in subscript attached to the second downward stroke of the "h".
A "d" with an "a" placed in subscript below it, possibly open and connected to the "d".
A "u" with a descender, standing for "ui".
An "s" and and "r" sharing the same descender.
A standard "ar" abbreviation whose descender is also the descender of a following "r".

note.p: Hand A in the Gaelic Notes in the Book of Deer

Jackson (1972): (p.12) Writing commences small, then varies in size. (p.13) It could date from the early to mid-12th century and must date from after 1038 at the earliest, as this is when Máel Snechta, whose grant he records, became mormaer of Moray. (p.16) Contemporary with B; late 11th/early 12th centuries?
Hand B in the Gaelic Notes in the Book of Deer
Jackson (1972): (p.13) Similar to A; makes much use of margins to keep his text together. (p.16) Contemporary with A; late 11th/early 12th centuries?
Hand C in the Gaelic Notes in the Book of Deer
Jackson (1972): (p.13) Uses paler and browner ink. Writing is spidery. More use of lenition marks. (p.15) Later than A and B. (p.16) "lateish in the period" [what is the period?]
Hand D in the Gaelic Notes in the Book of Deer

Jackson (1972): (p.14) Less formal. More use of m-suspension and abbreviations for mac and meic. Use of continental "g" (fer leiginn). (p.15) Later than A and C [and therefore B?]. (p.16) No earlier than 1131.
Hand E in the Gaelic Notes in the Book of Deer
Jackson (1972): (p.15): Wrote the Charter of David I. (p.16) A continental hand, with Hiberno-Saxon influences. (p.16) Late in the period.
Scribe of main text in the Book of Deer

This is the scribe of 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' in London, BL MS. Egerton 2899 and a set of Columban poems in Edinburgh, NLS Adv. MS 72.1.31. Black has suggested that he was a MacEwen working for the Campbells of Glenorchy.
On the whole, the scribe follows the conventions of medieval Gaelic orthography and restricts himself to the most conventional abbreviations.

The scribe displays a curious attitude towards lenition, often omitting it from monosyllables ending with /X'/ (e.g. nac, q1d not nach. At the same time, lenition markers are added where lenition would not normally be written (e.g. mainḋir, q2b. There is also one occasion where lenition is used to indicate eclipsis (q10a). The absence of lenition from final /X'/ may be designed to represent Scottish Gaelic pronounciation in some way, but I am yet to find a way of making sense of the feature along these lines.

He also tends to add a hair-stroke flick towards the upper right above the letter “i”, in the absence of any other diacritic. This closely resembles an acute accent but is probably meant merely as a minim marker. Examination of words in which “i” really should have an acute accent (e.g. q17b, “nac bí”; q24c, “tísat”) reveals no reliable visual indicator of when the flick is an accent or not, so accents on “i” are included in the diplomatic text simply when they would be expected in mainstream Classical Gaelic orthography.

handNote.note: Hand M in NLS Adv. MS 72.1.33.

note.p: Black's Hand K (NLS Adv. 72.1.33)

Like James Beaton's, this hand makes occasional brief interventions in Transcription 5.2 (NLS Adv. MS. 72.1.33). It is mucher neater than James Beaton's and the main scribes, with each stroke an angular block strongly distinguished from the others.

Rev. John Beaton (c. 1640-1715) attended grammar school in Inveraray and graduated M.A. from Glasgow University in 1668. He was minister of Kilninian in Mull by 1679. In the 1680s, he was involved with the MacLeans of Duart in their ultimately doomed effort to resist Campbell domination of Mull. Then, in the 1690s, Rev. Beaton was removed from Kilninian, possibly due to his failure to adequately distance himself from Episcopalianism. He travelled to Ireland, where, in 1700, in Coleraine (Co. Derry), he famously met with and assisted Edward Lhuyd (1660-1709) in his investigations into Scottish Gaelic. At some point, he returned to Mull and died at Torrelock, not far from Kilninian, in 1714. Further reading: Bannerman, 1998: 35-39
Black's Hand D (NLS Adv. 72.1.33)
EUL La. III.21

- "a good, clear hand varying in size from average to large" (Black, 2011) - tendency to use accents frequently (related to stress patterns in Latinate vocab?); difficult to distinguish from hairstrokes on "i" in minim clusters. - subtle use of word division (e.g. copula plus prep. as well as copula plus pronoun). - flexible use of abbreviations (e.g. sed-abbreviation for "echt"; tironian et for "it").

The hand that produced the quatrain is identifiable as that of Domhnall Gorm only by the signature. This was a popular name among the MacDonalds of Sleat during the 16th and early 17th centuries so it is presumed to be one of this clan's chiefs. Interest in poetry on the part of the clan's senior members is attested in the next century through their patronage of Cathal Mac Mhuirich (Black 1976–78: 332–339). Domhnall Gorm Mór seems to be the leading candidate due to him being known to have visited Edinburgh on several occasions (MacDonald & MacDonald 1904: 34–35). In the absence of more detailed evidence, any explanation as to how he came to interact with the Sinclairs and their manuscripts must remain speculative.

Domhnall Gorm's hand is neat, professional, and his command of the orthography, language, and poetics of the learned classes appears on the whole to be sound. The possibility that the quatrain and signature were inscribed for Domhnall Gorm should be borne in mind. Assuming it is Domhnall Gorm's own hand, this is an interesting specimen of aristocratic high-level literacy.
No other works in this hand, or attributed to Domhnall Gorm, are known.

This individual is unidentified but they appear to have been a physician active in Islay in the 16th century. In John Rylands MS. Ir 35 (fol. 67r), he records a series of treatments performed there and makes reference to the same region in NLS Adv. 72.1.27, fol. 3v. They also add frequent notes to MS14. In each of these cases and in that of MS17, Hand24 is interacting with a Beaton manuscript alongside Beaton scribes and glossators so he was evidently closely associated with this family, if not a member himself.

handNote.surname: mac Iollainn Mhic an Leagha Ruaidh

note.p: This scribe appears to be based in Ireland. He contributes to manuscripts associated with Sligo and Kildare. In MS17 (fol. 100r6), he calls Niall Óg mac Néill Mhic Beathadh "mo sesi", which could mean either "my friend" or, less likely, "my patron" and states that he wrote his potion of MS17 for him. Bannerman (2015: 7–8) points out that the Beatons claims to be relatively close relations of Meic an Leagha Ruaidh.
Hand G/H(?)/I(?) in NLS Adv. 72.1.33
Hand 5 in NLS Adv. 72.1.40; hand of Section B of NLS Adv. 72.1.31
Lord of the Isles (1386–1408)
Intervenes briefly in NLS Adv. 72.1.48, at fol. 12v
Scribe (?) and first witness of the MacLeod Fosterage Contract (1614).
Minister of Bracadale; witness of the MacLeod Fosterage Contract (1614).
Minister of Duirinish; witness of the MacLeod Fosterage Contract (1614).
Witness of the MacLeod Fosterage Contract (1614).
Hand 1 in NLS Adv. 72.1.27; "akin to those of Dáibhí Ó Cearnaigh, the Ó Ceannamháins and John Beaton in EUL MS. Laing III 21 and BL MS. Add. 15,582".
Intervenes briefly in Hand 1's text in NLS Adv. 72.1.27.
Scribe of 'Mór in broinsgel' in NAS RH. 13/40.
Address Sir Norman McLeod in RIA E.i.3.
Hand 2 in NLS Adv. 72.1.27
Hand 3 in NLS Adv. 72.1.27
Scribe and redactor of the Black Book of Clanranald.
Hand 4 in NLS Adv. 72.1.27
Hand 6 in NLS Adv. 72.1.27
Hand 7 in NLS Adv. 72.1.27
Hand 8 in NLS Adv. 72.1.27
Hand 2 in NLS Adv. 72.1.1
Main scribe of NLS Adv. 72.1.48
Scribe of 'Do bheirim barr búadha is áigh' in TCD 1362a.
Hand appears in NLS Adv. 72.1.4
Hand appears in NLS Adv. 72.1.4

The main scribe of the Argyll-O'Donnell Agreement, which he wrote out in 1560. He has not been identified and Black (2017) has stated that he could have been supplied by either Ó Domhnaill or Argyll. As Argyll is very much the dominant party in the arrangement, it seems marginally more likely that he supplied the scribe.
The hand is generally careful and elegant, employing minimal abbreviation. It is somewhat eccentric orthographically, however (e.g. "tigerrna" for tigerna; "ghaodheal" for Ghaoidheal).
Hand H in RIA A.v.2.
The hand that writes out the witness list in the Argyll-O'Donnell Agreement (1560).
The hand that wrote out Ó Domhnaill's signature in the Argyll-O'Donnell Agreement (1560); it is possible that this is An Calbhach Ó Domhnaill's (d. 1566) own hand.

The main hand of RIA A.iv.3 (743), a collection of bardic poetry, Hand62 writes in a fairly standard 17th-century Gaelic bookhand. It maintains a lot of continuity with the Gaelic minuscule familiar from medieval manuscripts while also having developed in various ways. A distinctive feature is his tendency to add flourishes, where possible, to word-final characters and to noticeably elongate horizontal strokes.

Based on the focus of the poems he transcribes and on the manuscript's subsequent history, he was probably based in Ireland, although it is not clear where. His activity can be dated to the latter two thirds of the 17th century based on a terminus post quem of some of the texts he transcribes and a terminus ante quem of the decline of the Classical tradition in which he is evidently immersed.

handNote.surname: mac Maoil Mhuire Ó Mhaoil Chonaire

note.p: Seanchán mac Maoil Mhuire Ó Mhaoil Chonaire (fl. 1473) was a member of the prominent Ó Maoil Chonaire family of historians and poets, who were based mainly in Connacht. Seanchán mac Maoil Mhuire was responsible for transcribing and quite possibly compiling section 4 (cols 128–216) of YBL (TCD H.2.16 (1318)), a collection of bardic poetry. His hand is somewhat untidy by the standards of high-class medieval Gaelic manuscripts. Relative size of characters can vary markedly within the same word and strokes sporadically extend beyond the writing track. Taller letters can appear slanted and serifs are sometimes insufficiently pronounced to prevent minim confusion. That being said, ascenders and descenders are usually distinguished clearly, variation in stroke width contributes to letter forms, and serifs are usually in place and visible.
Completes a text begun by Neil Beaton (Hand17) in NLS Adv. MS 72.1.33 (MS5).

Hand65 is the anonymous amanuensis to Marianus Scotus (ob. 1082) in Codex Palatino-Vaticanus No. 830. Ó Cuív (1990: 50) has described him as writing “in a very fine hand with letter-forms similar to those found in Irish manuscripts of eleventh and twelfth centuries”. He tells us in the first of the two notes included in the corpus that he is from Ireland but spent time in Scotland and is now based in a monastery in Mainz with Marianus.
Hand 1 of NLS Adv. 72.1.3.
Writes out an elegy on Allan of Clanranald (ob. 1715).
Hand of The Seven Wise Masters (+ further texts?) in NLS Adv. 72.1.39.
Hand 2 of NLS Adv. 72.1.3.
Signs EUL Laing III.21
Hand 3 of NLS Adv. 72.1.3.
Adds a note to NLS Adv. 72.1.3 identifying Gilla Padrig Ó Toindidh as one of the main scribes.
Writes the (psuedo-)historical text on pp.780-785 of TCD MS 1337/4.
Scribe of the crosántacht 'Mór mo mholadh ar Mhac Colla' in TCD MS 1337/4

This hand not only cannot be associated with a known scribe but cannot even be grouped in confidence with other interventions. This is probably because not enough has been written in this hand for a sound palaeographical analysis to be made. Note that this tag is a generic placeholder rather than an effort to identify a single hand.
